data.title: Directed by John Ford (1971)
data.meta_description: A documentary about the life and films of director John Ford.
data.text:
Ask a legend how he became one, and you’ll either receive a myth or a lie in response.

That is the experience of Peter Bogdanovich’s “Directed by John Ford;” a documentary on the icon’s cultural impact — centered around interviews with his contemporaries, colleagues, and the man himself: John Ford.

With over 120 films to his name, and many more derived from it, Ford might well be called the most influential director of all time. From Orson Welles to Steven Spielberg, Clint Eastwood, and Martin Scorsese - their stories, and essentially all of modern cinema, begin with Ford.

As Welles said, “With Ford at his best, you get a sense of what the earth is made of.”

But Ford doesn’t…

John Ford was a comedy genius! You may not get that from watching any of his films—the comic relief is routinely the weakest element in even his greatest works. But I swear to you, watching crotchety old Pappy Ford stonewall poor fresh faced, wet behind the ears Peter Bogdanovich in front of a Monument Valley backdrop is among the funniest things I ever have seen. This kid thought he was gonna get actual insight from the Old Master. Instead he asks how Ford shot a particular sequence and he gets told “with a camera.” Peter inquires about themes, Ford yells “cut!” It’s pure gold. These two should’ve starred in a sitcom together.

In all seriousness I think I may understand…

A Love letter to the man, the art, the legacy; matching years of film history generations between Wayne, Stewart, O’Hara, Fonda; being interviewed in 1969 and the some unabashed Ford fanboys formed by Spielberg, Scorsese, Hill and Eastwood (and Bogdanovich himself of course) in 2005, all spilling some knowledgeable insights to their love and fascination to the man’s craft.

But the best parts being the brief interviews with the man himself and the beautiful sections narrated by the ultimate Ford geek, Orson Welles, narrating through the beauty of some of the greatest things the man ever filmed – which reminded me of Scorsese’s A Personal Journey Through American Movies; where his full personality and artistry is really captured on camera,…
